poem:
Visitor Levy in the Land of Song  

In the valleys deep, a silent fee—  
each night, a whisper of coins,  
campside tales exchanged for shillings,  
the dragon's breath counting them.  
  
By the firelight,  
dreams of green hills,  
a 75p echo, a melody woven,  
culture's thread,  
binding,  
rich as loomed wool.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Wales may introduce visitor levy for people staying overnight People who stay in Wales overnight, including children, are set to be charged a visitor levy under a scheme that could raise up to £33m a year to be ploughed back into tourism and culture. All visitors would be charged 75p a night to stay in campsites and hostels and £1.25 for all other accommodation including hotels, B&Bs and holiday lets. A bill giving local authorities". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
